messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, John Cowan <cowan@...> wrote:
>
> Anthony Grahn scripsit:
>
>
> > I know the goal might be to produce something like Spanish with it's
> > universal spelling, phonemic letters and huge variety of accents. But
> > this can not be done with English in its current state. The various
> > accents have evolved in an incompatible manner over the centuries
> > because the language was insufficiently phonetic to begin with.
>
> Well, no. Orthodox spelling worked well for Southern English around
1500.
> And how good the writing system is in no way influences what's going to
> happen to the language: Latin broke up into a whole bunch of mutually
> unintelligible languages, anything up to 45 of them depending on how
> you count -- yet its orthography was excellent for the time it was
> written down.
>

Being phonemic in Southern English of the 1500s does not mean it is
phonemic in any other time or place. It was certainly not adequate for
19th century Australians or 18th century north Americans as proven by
Webster's project. And I'll bet it was mightily vexing even for the
Irish just across that tiny sea.

I did do not claim a quasi-phonemic writing system is *sufficient* to
prevent a language from drifting, I claim it is probably *necessary*
to prevent that drift. And note that English is changing far more
rapidly than the languages of the classical period: Attic Greek is
still almost intelligible to modern Greeks, but the language of any
district in England of just 1000 years ago is not to modern Britons
let alone that of 2500 years ago.

Anyway this is all way off topic.
